p: The Ashratkhona Mausoleum is located in the old part of Samarkand, near Registan, and was built in 1464 during the Timurid era, in the time of Amir Temur's grandson, Mirzo Ulughbek.
about: The Ashratkhona Mausoleum is located on the outskirts of the old city of Samarkand and is considered an architectural monument of Samarkand. Until recently, it was known as 'Ishratkhona', but researchers from the Samarkand State Museum-Reserve emphasize that its original name was 'Ashratkhona' (meaning 'ten rooms' in Arabic-Persian) and that the name had changed in pronunciation over time. The name 'Ashratkhona' was also given conditionally, connected to the political crisis that occurred in the Bukhara Khanate in the 18th century. During that time, wars between tribes and repeated invasions caused a plague outbreak, leading the population to abandon Samarkand. In the era of Emir Shohmurod of Bukhara, when Samarkand was rebuilt, settlers from different regions, lacking complete knowledge, gave ancient monuments names of their own. The 'Samariya' work, written in the 1830s, mentions the Ashratkhona Mausoleum. Based on the work, it can be said that this mausoleum was fully constructed in 1963 on the orders of Habiba Sultan for her daughter, Sultan Hovandbeka. Later, it became a dynastic tomb where 23 women and children were buried. After the Timurids lost power and the Shaybanids came, mausoleums and madrasahs related to the dynasty were neglected. This neglect continued during the Russian Empire and Soviet Union periods, leaving it to fall into ruin. For example, during the 1897 earthquake, the mausoleum suffered severe damage, and in 1902 its dome collapsed.
